awd_titl_txt: Children's Understanding of Indirect Attacks on Credibility
awd_abstract_narration:
When children allege sexual abuse, their report becomes central to assessing whether the crime occurred. However, children are susceptible to suggestion -- both from those who aim to influence their reports and those who aim to establish what children are alleging. Given children's susceptibility to courtroom questioning, the manner in which children are questioned about prior suggestive influence is incredibly important. How do children understand when attorneys are attacking the credibility of their reports, and how does the subtle phrasing of attacks influence children's responses? This investigation will assess how attorneys are questioning children in recent cases of alleged sexual abuse, as well as how children understand and respond to such questions. The findings can provide concrete recommendations for those questioning children about alleged crimes, helping to establish productive techniques that elicit accurate responses. In doing so, the proposed research has the potential to improve legal decision making in cases involving children, by providing questioning methods that better distinguish true from false allegations of abuse.

The researchers will utilize a mixed-methods approach. First they will conduct a systematic field assessment of how children are questioned in recent cases of alleged abuse. The findings will provide an indication of the frequency, content, context, and responsiveness to such assessments of credibility about suggestive influence. Second, a series of laboratory studies will assess children's comprehension and response patterns to such questions, with the materials developed in tandem with the findings from the field assessment to approximate courtroom questioning. In the laboratory studies, the researchers will also include questioning alternatives not used frequently by attorneys. Such findings will assess the boundaries on what children understand. Furthermore, doing so can result in producing alternatives that meet the needs of legal actors questioning children about suggestive influence, while allowing children to provide accurate and complete responses.

por.por_cntn:
Consider the question, “Did your mom help you remember?” Young children are likely to have a positive perception of their mother and of how she can help. Children are unlikely to recognize that the questioner could be implying something else, such as insinuating that the mother may have influenced the child through questioning, or worse, coached the child to make a false report. Our project assessed how often these kinds of subtle attacks on credibility occur in criminal investigations of alleged child sexual abuse, as well as how children respond to these questions in the laboratory.

We found that 9% of all attorney questioning to children asks about suggestive influence, truthfulness, or coaching, and that 66% of these questions were indirect. We then conducted a series of three laboratory studies, interviewing children (n = 458 total) one-on-one to assess how children would respond to these kinds of subtle questions. We found that children, even older children (e.g. 12-year-olds) sometimes acquiesced, or said yes to, subtle questions that imply coaching (e.g. “Did your mom practice with you what to say?” or “Did your mom help you remember?”), when in fact no coaching occurred. In fact, acquiescence rates were quite high in some of our studies among the younger children (e.g. overall rate of 39% for 5-10-year-olds in our first laboratory study across subtle question-types and age). Children’s rate of saying “yes,” or acquiescing, went down as the overtness of the question increased (e.g. “Did your mom tell you what happened?”), as well as when children’s age increased.

We also found that when non-offending caregivers were supportive of children’s disclosures (e.g. saying “I believe you. You need to tell a police officer”), acquiescence rates were higher; meaning that as children received more support from non-offending caregivers without coaching occurring, they were more likely to assent to the subtle question (e.g. “helping”), not recognizing the implicit attack on their credibility or that such response might signal to others that they were coached. Furthermore, children rely on parental support to inform whether they think others will believe a child disclosing to further disclosure recipients (e.g. the police), aligning their own believability evaluations with that of trusted adults (e.g. when parents don’t believe a child, children think neither will the police).

Finally, we learned that, at least for the older children, it’s not just that acquiescence increases when a non-offending parent is supportive – but specifically it’s when the parents support is consistent with the truthfulness of the child’s disclosure. So when the non-offending parent is helping the child in getting back to the truth (supporting a child truthfully disclosing an adult transgression or discouraging a child from disclosing when the child is making a false report), children are interpreting the mother as helping them remember what happened, and acquiescing to implied coaching questions which may make them look coached to investigative interviewers, attorneys, and other decision-makers. In all of these scenarios important to remember that no coaching occurred by the non-offending parent, and so acquiescence implies the mother coached their reports when she simply supported truth-telling. This means that children who have supportive non-offending caregivers may be more likely to look like they were coached when questioned using current investigative practices than children falsely denying abuse, or those who are truthfully disclosing but with unsupportive non-offending caregivers. Given our findings from the field, we expect that these kinds of miscommunications are common.
